Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature distribution in a rod over time is modeled by the heat equation \\(u_t = k u_{xx}\\), where \\(u_t\\) is the time derivative of temperature, \\(u_{xx}\\) is the second spatial derivative, and \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We explore the effect of applying a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) to the initial temperature distribution, particularly how this transform impacts the system dynamics.

If, at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), an inverse Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}^{-1}\\) is applied as an intervention and then the system is allowed to evolve under \\(u_t = k u_{xx}\\), will the temperature profile at \\(u(x,T)\\) for T > t_1 depend only on the original Fourier transform or also on the inverse applied?
Explanation: The intervention with \\(\\mathcal{F}^{-1}\\) modifies the state of the system again, possibly restoring or altering details of the original spatial temperature distribution. This makes the final state \\(u(x, T)\\) dependent not only on the original Fourier transform but also significantly on the inverse transform process applied mid-evolution.
